title: Welcome!
text:
I am available to tutor math, science, and standardized tests. More detailed information on my subject expertise can be found in this post.
A little about me. My background is in math, statistics, physics, and ecology. I am a PhD candidate in Quantitative Ecology and Resource Management and an MS student in Statistics at the University of Washington. I have instructed numerous math and statistics course in recent years, both in person and online. Throughout these teaching experiences, what I consistently found most rewarding was the one-on-one or small group tutoring that I did during office hours. Coming out of those experiences, I have decided to start a small tutoring business with which I can continue just those sorts of rewarding teaching moments.
I am currently available only for limited hours while I complete and defend my dissertation.

title: What Can You Tutor?
text:
Math

Calculus
Introductory Statistics
Linear Algebra
Ordinary and Partial Differential Equations
Advanced Statistical Modeling
Spatial Statistics

Computer Science

Introductory Programming
Python
R

Physics

Introductory Mechanics
Introductory Electricity and Magnetism
Introductory Special Relativity
Introductory Quantum Mechanics

Biology

Ecology and Ecological Modeling

Standardized Tests

SAT
GRE
AP Calculus
AP Statistics
AP Physics


I am also willing to tutor high school level subjects on a case-by-case basis for motivated students. If you would like tutoring for a specific subject that is not listed, or if you are unsure if it falls under one of these categories, please contact me at okasaki-tutoring@gmail.com and I would be happy to clarify.

title: What Can I Expect?
text:
Booking Your First Appointment
First we will determine the time, location, and price of your appointment. This coordination can be done over email, phone, or text depending on your personal preference. Once you have booked your initial appointment, I will ask that you send me the following information. Different professors can have very different takes on the same subject. In order for me to provide the best possible service for you, I will review these materials before your appointment.

a course syllabus
the name of any textbooks you are using
the topic you would like to discuss
(optional) the homework assignment you would like to discuss
(optional) any specific questions you have at the moment
(optional) any relevant notes or slides from your professor

If you would prefer, I am happy to schedule a complimentary 15 minute call over Zoom or phone to discuss what you would like to cover during our sessions.


Pricing
As a highly qualified and specialized tutor, with a PhD and experience teaching college-level classes, I will ultimately be charging a base rate of $100-$150/hour. However, at this early stage of my business, I am charging a base rate of $50/hour in exchange for testimonials and reviews. A very limited number of sliding scale appointments are available on a case-by-case basis for those who cannot afford this rate.
If you wish to meet in-person outside of my home, I will charge for any travel time beyond 30 minutes round trip, at the same rate as our appointment.


Policies
If you arrive late to our appointment, the appointment will still end on time and I will charge you for the full time length of our appointment. If you arrive more than 15 minutes late I reserve the right to cancel your appointment, although in this case I will only charge you for my actual time (15 minutes + travel time). Appointments cancelled less than 24 hours in advance will incur a cancellation fee equal to the 15 minute late fee.
Payment is due immediately following our appointment, at the negotiated price. In the event of non-payment, no further appointments will be scheduled until payment is received.

title: About
text: Connie Okasaki is a PhD candidate at the University of Washington, an NSF Graduate Research Fellow, an ARCS Fellow, and a Pre-Doctoral Instructor. She has taught Introduction to Probability and Statistics and Introduction to Quantitative Ecology at the undergraduate and graduate levels. She has an excellent academic record, and glowing reviews from her time as an instructor. She is passionate about teaching and is trained in evidence-based and equity-focused teaching strategies in the NSF-funded STEP-UP program at UW. Her priority is providing a comfortable and compassionate learning environment for her students.
